question: Pyruvate dehydrogenase multienzyme complex carries out all the following reactions EXCEPT:
exp: PDH reaction Oxidative decarboxylation reaction (option a is correct) Pyruvate is conveed to acetyl-CoA - (option c is correct) Acetyl group is combined with CoA cofactor - (option d is correct) NADH is produced in PDH reaction. No substrate level production of ATP - (option b is wrong)
opc: Produce an acetyl group from pyruvate
opd: Combine the acetyl group with a cofactor

question: Which of the following is true for Creatine-Phosphate Shuttle:
exp: Creatine-Phosphate shuttle is used to transpo ATP from Mitochondria to Cytoplasm. Option 2- Citrate Shuttle Option 3- Malate Shuttle Option 4- Glycerol phosphate shuttle
opa: Transpo ATP from mitochondria to cytoplasm
opb: Transpo Acetyl CoA from mitochondria to cytoplasm
opc: Takes NADH from cytoplasm and delivers NADH in the mitochondria
opd: Takes NADH from cytoplasm and delivers FADH2 in the mitochondria

question: All of the following are true about pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency, EXCEPT
exp: PDH complex deficiency results in: Rise in pyruvate Upregulating other reactions of pyruvate metabolism (reduction to lactate by NADH-requiring LDH leading to lactic acidosis.) The most common form of PDH complex deficiency is caused by mutations to E1.
opa: Mutation in the E1 component of PDH is the most common
opc: Ketogenic diet rich in leucine is given as a treatment

question: All of the following are tightly bound to component enzymes of pyruvate dehydrogenase, EXCEPT
Malate shuttle is impoant in:
exp: Malate shuttle is more impoant in the liver and cardiac muscles as these organs require a continuous supply of energy. Whereas Glycerol-P-shuttle is a shoer shuttle and provides a quick source of ATPs as compared to the Malate shuttle. So it is present in brain & skeletal muscles, where energy is needed quickly in case of an emergency.

question: Thiamine deficiency results in decrease energy production, because TPP:
exp: Link reaction & TCA cycle requires 5 coenzymes: Lipoic acid and four B-complex Vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B5). Due to this reason, Thiamine (vitamin B1) deficiency results in decrease energy production (also CNS problems because Brain cells depend on this aerobic reaction) as TCA & link reaction both are responsible for energy production in cells.
opc: Is cofactor for pyruvate dehydrogenase and alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
opd: Interferes with Energy production from amino acids

question: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase complex has all enzyme components EXCEPT:
exp: PDH complex has 3 enzyme components: 1. E1: Pyruvate Dehydrogenase 2. E2: Dihydrolipoyl Transacetylase 3. E3: Dihydrolipoyl Dehydrogenase REGULATION OF PDH End Product Inhibition Covalent Modification Acetyl CoA (in fasting) NADH Active in dephosphorylated state Done by Insulin

question: Pyruvate utilisation is decreased in:
exp: PDH complex requires five coenzymes - Vitamin B1, B2, B3, B5 and Lipoic acid. Vitamin B1 deficiency - Beri-beri Beri- beri - |PDH activity - | pyruvate to acetyl-CoA conversion - low pyruvate utilization Vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B5) - decreased energy production and CNS problems (brain cells depend upon this aerobic reaction)

question: If aerobic glycolysis uses Glycerol-3-Phosphate shuttle, How many net ATPs are produced?
exp: The inner mitochondrial membrane is impermeable to NADH. Therefore, the NADH produced in the cytosol cannot directly enter the mitochondria. It enters mitochondria indirectly with the help of shuttles. e. g glycerol phosphate and malate shuttles. ATP yield in Aerobic glycolysis and Glycerol phosphate shuttle: Total ATP = 4 ATP + (-2 ATP) + 3 ATP = 5 ATP
